awd_titl_txt: Hyperbolic Manifolds, Geodesic Submanifolds, and Rigidity for Rank-1 Lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
Geometry is broadly focused on studying manifolds (multi-dimensional shapes) and their intrinsic properties, such as volume, curvature, and lengths of curves between two points on the manifold. In this field, understanding symmetries of a given manifold plays a key role in studying its other geometric properties. These symmetries are encoded in an algebraic construction called the fundamental group; this project aims at studying the connections between this group and geometry. Specifically, among hyperbolic manifolds there is a special class called "arithmetic" that tend to be the most symmetric and whose fundamental group has strong connections to number theory. This project aims to use new techniques in geometry and dynamics to study the fundamental group of hyperbolic manifolds in an attempt to understand when such a group is arithmetic and the ramifications of arithmeticity (or lack thereof) on the geometry of the associated manifold. Broader impacts of this project include work with undergraduates.

More specifically, the overarching goal of this research project is twofold -- to better understand the classification of hyperbolic manifolds and their geodesic geometry and to build a robust framework for exploring rigidity phenomenon for fundamental groups of finite-volume real, complex, quaternionic, and Cayley hyperbolic manifolds.  The principal investigator has recently made a series of advances that facilitate the development of geometric, group theoretic, and dynamical techniques for understanding the geodesic geometry of manifolds built by gluing submanifolds of arithmetic manifolds, as well as the development of superrigidity style techniques for lattices in the isometry group of real hyperbolic space. This project plans to continue to develop these new techniques with an eye toward geometric applications. Specifically, the project will address the following broad themes: 1) understanding constructions of both low- and high-dimensional hyperbolic manifolds and their geodesic submanifolds, 2) further developing a general framework for superrigidity results for rank-1 lattices, and 3) attempting to use recent advances in rank-1 rigidity as a mechanism to understand integrality of complex hyperbolic lattices and arithmeticity of quaternionic and Cayley hyperbolic spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In Euclidean space, the shortest distance between two points is a straight line. However, in more complex geometric settings—such as on spheres, saddles, or higher-dimensional manifolds—the shortest paths are not necessarily straight lines but instead follow the curvature of the space. These paths, known as geodesics, are (locally) distance-minimizing trajectories that reflect the intrinsic geometry of the shape (or manifold). Extending this concept, geodesic submanifolds are subsets of these manifolds that represent higher-dimensional generalizations of shortest paths, where any pair of points on the submanifold can be connected by a geodesic that remains entirely within the submanifold. For instance, a flat two-dimensional plane embedded in three-dimensional Euclidean space is a geodesic submanifold. These submanifolds have proven to be essential tools for studying the geometry of manifolds, particularly when the manifold is hyperbolic. This project achieved significant advances in understanding the relationship between geometry, dynamics, and number theory by investigating the prevalence of such geodesic submanifolds and their effects on the geometry of hyperbolic manifolds and their fundamental groups.

During the grant period, the PI and collaborators achieved a complete geometric characterization of arithmetic hyperbolic manifolds through their geodesic submanifolds in dimensions three and higher. Arithmetic manifolds are defined using number-theoretic techniques, and one particularly striking aspect of this characterization is the connection it reveals between number theory and differential geometry. This work completely resolved a long-standing open problem posed by Reid and McMullen, advancing our understanding of when hyperbolic manifolds admit highly symmetric geometric structures. A novel contribution of this research was the development of techniques for studying the rigidity of rank-1 lattices, which provide a new framework for analyzing representations of fundamental groups of hyperbolic spaces. The PI anticipates that this framework will continue to benefit the field in the future. For example, the PI and collaborators have already applied this framework successfully in subsequent works to study the rigidity of representations for fundamental groups of complex hyperbolic manifolds. This framework also has tangible geometric applications, including to the study of geodesic surfaces behavior under Dehn filling and contributions to Siu's immersion question, which explores the interplay between complex and differential geometry.

Beyond theoretical advancements, the grant also supported broader impacts. For example, it enabled the PI to co-organize a research conference, which resulted in the publication of a conference proceedings, as well as a "Log Cabin Workshop," a week-long research retreat designed for early-career mathematicians. The latter workshop provided participants with training on modern research topics, facilitated collaborative opportunities, and fostered professional connections. Additionally, the grant supported the PI in mentoring graduate students and disseminating research results to the broader community.
